== Causes ==
=== It Gets Better Project === {{Main|It Gets Better Project}} [[File:Dan Savage speaking at google about the it gets better project Victor Grigas IMG 4080.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Dan Savage speaking at Google about the It Gets Better Project]] On September 21, 2010, Savage founded the [[It Gets Better Project]] following the suicide of 15-year-old Billy Lucas, who was bullied for his perceived [[sexual orientation]]. The project encourages adults, both LGBT and otherwise, to submit videos assuring gay teenagers that life can improve after bullying in early life.<ref>Parker, Tara. (September 22, 2010) [http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/22/showing-gay-teens-a-happy-future/ Showing Gay Teenagers a Happy Future]. Well.blogs.nytimes.com. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> As of November 2013, the project had more than 50,000 user-created testimonials and had been viewed over 50 million times.<ref>[http://www.itgetsbetter.org/pages/about-it-gets-better-project/ "About"]. It Gets Better. Retrieved November 30, 2013.</ref>
=== Hump pornography festival === {{main|HUMP! (film festival)}} Savage has always been pro-[[pornography]], especially [[Internet pornography]]. He often remarks that the Internet was invented ''for'' pornography.
Savage coordinates the annual Hump pornography festival, which is made up of clips of up to five minutes on any pornographic topic, submitted by viewers. Winning submissions are shown in theaters around the United States, providing a unique experience as straight, gay male, bi, lesbian, and fetish porn are all shown together, one after another. Savage publicly destroys the submissions after conclusion of the festival.<ref>http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Hump2014/, consulted June 3, 2015</ref>
=== Political advocacy === [[Image:DanSavagecrop.jpg|thumb|right|Dan Savage at the 5th Avenue High School Musical Theatre Awards, 2006]] Savage tends to [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] political views, with pronounced contrarian and [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] streaks.<ref name="SFGate">{{cite web|author=Buchanan, Wyatt|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/10/21/DDGKTF7E2L39.DTL|title=Marriage Can Be Right For Us All, says Dan Savage. But Let's Not Get Carried Away With Monogamy|date=October 21, 2005|work=The [[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref> For example, he wrote that in 2000, suffering from the flu while on an assignment for [[salon.com]] to cover the [[Iowa caucuses]],<ref>[http://www.salon.com/politics2000/feature/2000/01/29/savage_reaction/index.html "The firestorm over 'Stalking Gary Bauer{{'"}}] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060308163753/http://www.salon.com/politics2000/feature/2000/01/29/savage_reaction/index.html |date=March 8, 2006 }}. ''Salon''. January 29, 2000. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> he was so angered by televised remarks in opposition to [[same-sex marriage]] by conservative [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential hopeful [[Gary Bauer]] that he abandoned his original plan "to follow one of the loopy conservative Christian candidates around—Bauer or Alan Keyes—and write something insightful and humanizing about him, his campaign, and his supporters".<ref name=stalking>{{cite web| last = Savage | first = Dan | title = Stalking Gary Bauer | work = Salon.com | date = January 25, 2000 | url = http://archive.salon.com/politics2000/feature/2000/01/25/bauer/ | accessdate = May 6, 2008}}</ref> Instead, he volunteered for the Bauer campaign with the intent to infect the candidate with his [[flu]]. He wrote that he licked doorknobs and other objects in the campaign office, and handed Bauer a [[saliva]]-coated pen, hoping to pass the virus on to Bauer and his supporters. (Later he said much of his article had been fictitious). He also registered and participated in the caucus, which was illegal, as Savage was not an Iowa resident. He was charged and pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of fraudulent voting in a caucus, and was sentenced to a year's [[probation]], 50 hours of community service, and a $750 fine.<ref>[http://www.dmregister.com/news/stories/c4789004/12880264.html ''Des Moines Register'' article].</ref><ref>[http://qrd.org/qrd/media/radio/thiswayout/summary/newswrap/2000/N659-11.13.00 NewsWrap for the week ending November 11, 2000], ''This Way Out'' program #659, November 13, 2000.</ref><ref>Dan Savage, [http://thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=3092 Germ Warfare], ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]'', January 27 – February 2, 2000.</ref>
Savage frequently mentions political issues in his column, particularly issues that affect family planning, birth control, and sexuality. He often encourages readers to get involved and/or voice a positive or negative opinion about a politician or public official.
====Campaign for the neologism "santorum"==== After [[Rick Santorum]], then a U.S. Senator from Pennsylvania, made comments in 2003 to a reporter comparing homosexual sex to [[bestiality]] and [[incest]], Savage assailed Santorum in his column. Later, he sponsored a contest that led to the term ''[[campaign for the neologism "santorum"|santorum]]'' being used to refer to "the frothy mixture of lube and fecal matter that is sometimes a byproduct of anal sex".<ref>uma, [http://la.indymedia.org/news/2003/12/97071_comment.php Anal Sex Byproduct Named for Senator Santorum] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061102182528/http://la.indymedia.org/news/2003/12/97071_comment.php |date=November 2, 2006 }}, Indymedia.org, December 11, 2003.</ref> (See [[Campaign for the neologism santorum]].) Savage set up a website to publicize this application of the term.<ref name="valuewar">{{cite book|first=Paul Ryan |last=Brewer|pages=82–86|year=2007|title=Value War: Public Opinion and the Politics of Gay Rights|publisher= Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc.|isbn=978-0-7425-6211-0}}</ref> In 2010, Savage offered to take down his website if Rick Santorum would agree to donate US$5 million to a [[gay rights]] group.<ref name="unproblema">{{cite news|url=http://www.ilpost.it/2010/09/08/rick-santorum-ha-un-problema-con-google/|publisher=www.ilpost.it|date=September 8, 2010|language=Italian|title=Rick Santorum ha un problema con Google|work=[[Il Post]]|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name="santorumacnkowledgesanalsexproblem" /> The organization, [[Freedom to Marry]], advocates on behalf of [[same-sex marriage]] in the United States.<ref name="santorumacnkowledgesanalsexproblem">{{cite news|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|url=http://motherjones.com/mojo/2011/02/santorum-acknowledges-anal-sex-problem|accessdate=May 14, 2011|date=February 17, 2011|first=Stephanie |last=Mencimer|publisher=motherjones.com|title=Santorum Acknowledges Anal Sex Problem}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2010/09/rick-santorum-vs-google/18960/|accessdate=May 14, 2011|work=[[The Atlantic Wire]]|title=Rick Santorum vs. Google|first=Max|last=Fisher|date=September 7, 2010}}</ref> Savage told ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' in 2010, "If Rick Santorum wants to make a $5 million donation to [the gay marriage group] Freedom to Marry, I will take it down. Interest starts accruing now."<ref name="mencimer">{{Cite news| last = Mencimer| first = Stephanie | title = Rick Santorum's Anal Sex Problem| newspaper = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]| date = September 2010| url = http://motherjones.com/politics/2010/08/rick-santorum-google-problem-dan-savage | accessdate = September 12, 2010}}</ref> Evan Wolfson, executive director of Freedom to Marry, responded in a statement to ''[[Metro Weekly]]'', "Support for Freedom to Marry's national campaign would be welcome—and a good way for Rick Santorum to start cleaning up the discriminatory mess he and his companions have made."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/poliglot/2010/09/wolfson-wants-santorum-to.html |publisher=www.metroweekly.com |work=[[Metro Weekly]] |title=Wolfson Wants Santorum "To Start Cleaning Up" His "Mess" |first=Chris |last=Geidner |date=September 7, 2010 |accessdate=May 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626183946/http://metroweekly.com/poliglot/2010/09/wolfson-wants-santorum-to.html |archivedate=June 26, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Santorum condemned the campaign and accused Savage of [[defamation|defaming]] him. Savage responded by further denouncing Santorum and accused him of propagating [[discrimination]] against the LGBT community through his viewpoints.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-david/savage-santorum-_b_903875.html|title=Dan Savage vs. Rick Santorum|publisher=Huffington Post|date=21 July 2011}}</ref>
In 2009 Savage invited his readers to vote to define ''[[saddlebacking]]'' as "the phenomenon of Christian teens engaging in unprotected anal sex to preserve their virginities."<ref>[http://www.saddlebacking.com "Saddlebacking"]. ''saddlebacking.com''. Retrieved on October 6, 2015.</ref> He was protesting the vocal support given to [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|California Proposition 8]] by [[Rick Warren]] (pastor of Saddleback Church), and [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama's]] invitation to Warren to give the invocation at his inauguration. When Savage vowed to boycott [[Utah]] due to strong [[Mormon]] support for Proposition 8 ("Fuck you, Utah—we’re going to big, blue Colorado"), the ''[[Salt Lake City Weekly]]'' dropped Savage's column: "all Utahns aren’t to blame."<ref>Edroso, Roy (2008) "[http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2008/11/salt_lake_weekl.php Salt Lake Weekly Fires Dan Savage for Utah Boycott; Voice Protests] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923152521/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2008/11/salt_lake_weekl.php |date=September 23, 2012 }}." ''The Village Voice'', Retrieved January 17, 2010.</ref>
Savage strongly supported the [[War in Iraq]] in October 2002, stating "Free your people, reform your societies, liberalize, and democratize... or we're going to come over there, remove you from power, free your people, and reform your societies for ourselves."<ref>Dan Savage, [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=12237 Say "YES" to War on Iraq], ''The Stranger'', October 17–23, 2002. Retrieved November 6, 2006.</ref> By the time of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|U.S. invasion in March 2003]], however, he opposed the war.<ref name="Against the War--For Now">Dan Savage, [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=13624 "Against the War—For Now"] March 13–19, 2003. Retrieved November 6, 2006.</ref>
Savage has also opposed state legislation proscribing the sale of [[sex toys]]. After an exposé by Kandiss Crone from [[WLBT]] in [[Jackson, Mississippi]] precipitated the arrest and fining of an adult video store owner, Savage suggested that readers send any sex toys that they needed to dispose of to Crone.<ref>Dan Savage, [https://archive.is/20070517095307/http://www.ocweekly.com/columns/savage-love/savage-love-what-is-good-sex-toy-etiquette/28468/ "What is good sex-toy etiquette?"], February 14, 2008. Retrieved February 17, 2008.</ref><ref>Kandiss Crone, [http://www.wlbt.com/Global/story.asp?s=7803180 "Adult Store Caught Selling Illegal Sex Toys"], January 30, 2008. Retrieved February 17, 2008.</ref>
===Local issues=== Savage's editorship of ''The Stranger'' has established him as a voice in local Seattle politics. His most high-profile commentary has been as an outspoken critic of the [[Teen Dance Ordinance]] and other crackdowns on all-ages events.
Savage argues that closing down supervised all-ages dance venues drives teens to boredom and reckless activities: "Places like Ground Zero and the [[Kirkland Teen Union Building|Kirkland Teen Center]] are invaluable from a law enforcement point of view. They keep kids out of, say, 7-Eleven parking lots or the homes of friends whose parents are away."<ref>Josh Feit and Dan Savage, "[http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=31362 Raving Mad]", ''The Stranger'', March 30 – April 5, 2006. Retrieved April 6, 2006.</ref>
===Other opinions=== [[File:2010 November 13 Dan Savage and Bill Savage.jpg|thumb|Dan Savage discussing [[sex education]] with his brother, Bill Savage, [[Northwestern University]] Senior Lecturer in English (2010)]] Savage initially supported the [[Iraq War]] and advocated military action against other Middle Eastern states, including [[Iran]] and [[Saudi Arabia]], saying, "Islamo-fascism is a regional problem, like European fascism—and the Middle East [has] to be remade just as Europe was remade." One week before the war began, Savage spoke against it, citing the inability of President [[George W. Bush]] to form a convincing case and sway the UN and [[NATO]] allies.<ref name="Against the War--For Now"/> By 2005 he deemed the situation "hopeless" and advocated an immediate troop withdrawal.<ref>Savage, Dan (August 18, 2005). [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=22626 "It's over, over there"]. ''The Stranger''.</ref>
Savage describes his view toward family as "conservative." His husband, Terry Miller, is a "stay-at-home dad" for the couple's [[LGBT adoption in the United States|adopted]] son. He has, however, expressed skepticism of "simplistic" views of [[monogamy]].<ref>Savage, Dan (September 23, 1999). [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=2070 Savage Love: I, Monogamous]. ''The Stranger''.</ref> In response to a letter asking "Is the AIDS crisis over?" Savage, in his October 22, 1997 column, answered simply, "Yes." Several weeks of columns were devoted in whole or in part to discussion of the issue.<ref>Savage, Dan (1998). ''Savage Love: Straight Answers from America's Most Popular Sex Columnist''. pp. 291–98.</ref><ref>Savage, Dan (November 19, 1997). "Savage Love" (column), ''[[SF Weekly]]''.</ref> Savage also opposes the tactics of the [[War on Drugs]], and opposes the prohibition of certain controlled substances.<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/advice/view/SavageLove/2009-05-28 New York Advice Column] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907143315/http://www.villagevoice.com/advice/view/SavageLove/2009-05-28 |date=September 7, 2009 }}. ''The Village Voice''. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref>
Savage stated in a column that he favors [[outing]] in some cases, specifically mentioning anti-gay activist Tyler Whitney. However, in the same column he noted that "I recently talked someone ''out'' of outing a public figure. A ''Savage Love'' reader was contemplating outing an innocuous celebrity back in April. I advised him against it because, as I wrote to him privately, outing is brutal and it should be reserved for brutes."<ref>Dan Savage, [http://www.avclub.com/content/node/62996 Savage Love] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626042106/http://www.avclub.com/content/node/62996 |date=June 26, 2007 }} (column), ''The A.V. Club'', June 20, 2007.</ref>
On the topic of child sexuality, Savage has said: {{quote|We live in a culture that's hysterical about children and assumes they have no sexual agency or desire. But anyone who can remember what they were like when they were 11 knows that kids are sexual, and whether it was messing around with their cousin, playing doctor with their neighbor, or making passes at people 10 years older, they were horny. So [[NAMBLA]] steps out to articulate all this, albeit in its usual highly dysfunctional and creepy way, and because we know what they say to be true on this issue, we've got to label them as insane perverts. Any attempt at rational discussion about youth sexuality and intergenerational sex is simply shouted down.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/home/articles/boy_crazy/ |title=Boston Magazine, Boy Crazy |author=Benoit Denizet-Lewis |date=May 2001 |publisher=Bostonmagazine.com |accessdate=October 7, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6610eRu6g?url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/scripts/print/article.php?asset_idx=200857 |archivedate=March 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>}} Savage has taken strong positions on sexual abuse of children. After being accused of attacking then-14 year old [[Anthony Rapp]] while drunk, actor [[Kevin Spacey]] issued a statement on [[Twitter]]<ref>{{cite tweet|last = Spacey|first = Kevin|user = kevinspacey|authorlink=Kevin Spacey|number = 924848412842971136|date = October 29, 2017|title = [Image of note.]|archive-url = https://archive.is/20171030053834/https://twitter.com/kevinspacey/status/924848412842971136|archive-date = October 30, 2017|dead-url = no}}</ref> which included [[coming out]] as gay.<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/oct/30/kevin-spacey-anthony-rapp-apologises-accused-sexual-advance-14-year-old-boy|date = October 30, 2017|accessdate = October 30, 2017|first = Stephanie|last = Convery|newspaper = [[The Guardian]]|title = Kevin Spacey apologises after being accused of sexual advance on 14-year-old actor|archive-date = November 1, 2017|dead-url = no|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171101201210/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/oct/30/kevin-spacey-anthony-rapp-apologises-accused-sexual-advance-14-year-old-boy}}</ref> Savage responded<ref>{{cite tweet|first = Dan|last = Savage|user = fakedansavage|title = Nope to Kevin Spacey's statement. Nope. There's no amount of drunk or closeted that excuses or explains away assaulting a 14-year-old child.|date = October 29, 2017|accessdate = November 13, 2017|number = 924862060562857984|archive-date = November 7, 2017|dead-url = no|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171107075312/https://twitter.com/fakedansavage/status/924862060562857984}}</ref> that there is "no amount of drunk or closeted that excuses or explains away assaulting a 14-year-old child."<ref name = NYT-Spacey>{{cite news|last = Victor|first = Daniel|title = Kevin Spacey criticized for using apology to Anthony Rapp to come out|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/arts/kevin-spacey-reaction.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171103003948/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/arts/kevin-spacey-reaction.html|archive-date=November 3, 2017|dead-url=no|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|date = October 30, 2017|accessdate = November 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last = John|first = Tara|title = People are mad that Kevin Spacey responded to a sexual misconduct allegation by coming out|url = http://time.com/5002057/kevin-spacey-anthony-rapp-coming-out/|newspaper = [[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date = October 30, 2017|accessdate = November 13, 2017}}</ref>
==Controversies== In a 2006 interview with the ''[[Daily Pennsylvanian]]'', Savage stated that then-[[Green Party (United States)|Green Party]] [[Pennsylvania United States Senate election, 2006|Senate]] candidate [[Carl Romanelli (politician)|Carl Romanelli]], who Savage claimed was partially funded by state Republicans for a [[spoiler effect]] against Democrat [[Bob Casey, Jr.|Bob Casey]], "should be dragged behind a pickup truck until there's nothing left but the rope". In the same interview, he stated, "Mr. Romanelli should go fuck himself."<ref>{{cite news|last=Morse |first=Stephen |date=October 12, 2006 |url=http://lamp.dailypennsylvanian.com/blogs/index.php?page=post&section=2&id=364 |title=Columnist says candidate should be 'dragged behind a pickup truck |work=[[The Daily Pennsylvanian]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219202931/http://lamp.dailypennsylvanian.com/blogs/index.php?page=post&section=2&id=364 |archivedate=February 19, 2008}}</ref> Immediately after the interview, Savage wrote, "I regret using that truck metaphor, and didn't mean it literally, and it was in poor taste, and I regret it."<ref>[http://slog.thestranger.com/2006/10/five_minutes_with_da_1#c475768 "Five Minutes with Dan"], October 12, 2006. Retrieved April 30, 2007.</ref>
On [[HBO]]'s ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' July 15, 2011, during a panel discussion of the [[United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2011|debt limit increase negotiations]] between the [[U.S. Congress]] and President [[Barack Obama]], Savage said in a stand-alone remark, "I wish the Republicans were all fucking dead."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/dan-savage-says-of-congressional-republicans-i-wish-they-all-were-fkin-dead-on-real-time/ |title=Dan Savage Says of Congressional Republicans 'I Wish They All Were F**kin' Dead' On ''Real Time''|publisher=Mediaite |date=July 16, 2011|accessdate=January 16, 2012}}</ref> He apologized for his remarks on his blog later the same night saying in part, "I don't feel that way. My dad is a Republican. (Well, he says he's an independent, but he hasn't voted for a Democrat since JFK. My dad is a Republican.)"<ref>{{cite web|last=Savage |first=Dan |url=http://slog.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2011/07/15/an-apology |title=An Apology|work=The Stranger|date=July 15, 2011|accessdate=January 16, 2012}}</ref>
Savage also came under scrutiny for an April 13, 2012, anti-bullying speech in which he encouraged high school students to "learn to ignore the bullshit in the Bible about gay people", prompting some students to leave the auditorium. Savage apologized on April 29 for calling the walkout "a pansy-assed move", saying, "I wasn't calling the handful of students who left pansies (2,800+ students, most of them Christian, stayed and listened), just the walkout itself." Savage stood by the central point of his speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2012/04/30/columnist-dan-savage-stands-by-comments-on-bullst-in-the-bible/?hpt=hp_c2|title=Columnist Dan Savage stands by comments on 'bulls**t in the Bible'|last=Gilgoff|first=Dan|date=April 30, 2012|publisher=CNN|accessdate=April 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/04/30/11477048-dan-savage-apologizes-for-criticizing-students-who-walked-out-of-lecture?lite |title=Dan Savage apologizes for criticizing students who walked out of lecture |first=Isolde |last=Raftery |work=[[msnbc.com]] |date=April 30, 2012 |accessdate=May 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504100543/http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/04/30/11477048-dan-savage-apologizes-for-criticizing-students-who-walked-out-of-lecture?lite |archivedate=May 4, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title= On "Bullshit" and "Pansy-Assed" |first= Dan |last= Savage |date= April 29, 2012 |newspaper= [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |url= http://slog.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2012/04/29/on-bullshit-and-pansy-assed |accessdate= May 7, 2012 }}</ref>
J. Bryan Lowder of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' stated that Savage "often takes heat for his less-than-refined statements on issues like the existence of male bisexuality, the responsibility of asexuals to 'come out' before dating, and, indeed, certain issues surrounding transgenderism."<ref name="Lowder">{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2011/11/04/did_dan_savage_deserve_to_be_glitter_bombed_.html|title=Did Dan Savage Deserve to be Glitter-Bombed?|last=Lowder|first=J. Bryan|date=November 4, 2011|publisher=Slate|accessdate=March 21, 2012}}</ref> Savage has repeatedly been the focus of controversy for his use of slurs regarding the transgender community, other remarks regarding trans issues, and for joking that the then Attorney General of Washington was trans (who was not, in fact, trans).<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/02/dan-savage-glitterbombed-oregon-transphobia-_n_1071627.html "Dan Savage Gets Glitterbombed, Called Transphobic At University Of Oregon"]. ''The Huffington Post''. Retrieved on October 6, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.thecollegefix.com/post/17843/ "Gay Activist Dan Savage Accused of 'Transphobia' - The College Fix"]. ''The College Fix''. Retrieved on October 6, 2015.</ref> He has been [[Glitter bombing|glitter bombed]] three times, twice in 2011 and once in 2012, by protesters who alleged that he is [[transphobia|transphobic]], among other accusations.<ref name="Lowder"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Hill-Meyer |first=Tobi |url=http://www.bilerico.com/2011/11/dan_savage_gets_glitter_bombed_for_being_transphob.php |title=Dan Savage Gets Glitter Bombed for Being Transphobic |publisher=The Bilerico Project |date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hill-Meyer |first=Tobi |url=http://www.bilerico.com/2011/11/dan_savage_glittered_again_student_arrested.php |title=Dan Savage Glittered Again, Student Arrested |publisher=The Bilerico Project |date=November 14, 2011 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Oommen |first=Isaac |url=http://vancouver.mediacoop.ca/photo/dan-savage-glitterbombed/9681 |title=Dan Savage Glitterbombed |publisher=Vancouver Media Co-op |date=January 21, 2012 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> In June 2014, during a seminar at the [[University of Chicago]] on [[social media]], Savage discussed his past use of the word "[[tranny]]". He objected to a student's request that he use the phrase "T-slur" instead, and gave examples of other slurs. Some students criticized him, claiming that he tried to make the student feel threatened and uncomfortable. A University representative said, "A guest used language that provoked a spirited debate. The speaker was discussing how hurtful words can be repurposed and used to empower; at no point did he direct any slurs at anyone."<ref> * {{cite web |url= http://chicagomaroon.com/2014/05/30/comments-at-iop-spark-controversy/ |title=The Chicago Maroon — Comments at IOP spark controversy |first=Christine |last= Schmidt |work=chicagomaroon.com |date=May 30, 2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014}} * {{cite web |url= http://politics.uchicago.edu/news/entry/iop-statement-on-commitment-to-diversity-inclusion |title=IOP Statement on Commitment to Diversity & Inclusion | |author=Institute of Politics | The University of Chicago |work=politics.uchicago.edu |date=May 27, 2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014}} * {{cite web |url= http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/379649/uchicago-students-dan-savages-use-t-slur-made-us-feel-unsafe-andrew-johnson |title=UChicago Students: Dan Savage's Use of 'T-Slur' Made Us Feel 'Unsafe' | National Review Online |first=Andrew |last=Johnson|work=nationalreview.com |date=June 5, 2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref> Savage later thanked the University for standing up for him and demanded an apology from those who had accused him of hatred towards trans people.<ref>Robby Soave, [http://reason.com/blog/2014/06/09/dan-savage-stands-up-to-the-speech-polic Dan Savage Stands Up to the Speech Police, Defends His Use of 'Tranny'], ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'', June 9, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://slog.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2014/06/07/about-that-hate-crime-i-committed-at-university-of-chicago |title=About That Hate Crime I Committed at University of Chicago | Slog |first=Dan |last=Savage |work=slog.thestranger.com |year=2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref>
==Works== {{Main|Dan Savage bibliography}} In addition to his advice column, Savage has written four books, edited one book, and authored various [[op-ed]] pieces in ''[[The New York Times]]''.
Savage coordinates the annual [[HUMP! (film festival)|Hump!]] film festival, which is made up of clips of up to five minutes on any pornographic topic, submitted by viewers. Winning submissions are shown in Seattle and Portland theaters, providing an unusual experience as straight, gay male, bi, lesbian, and fetish porn are all shown together, one after another. Savage publicly destroys the submissions after the festival is over.<ref name="phil_DanS">{{Cite web | title = Dan Savage Bringing Amateur Porn Film Festival to Philly in February | last = Middleton | first = Josh | work = Philadelphia Magazine | date = January 20, 2015 | accessdate = March 6, 2015 | url = http://www.phillymag.com/g-philly/2015/01/20/dan-savage-bringing-amateur-porn-film-fest-philly-february/ | language = | quote = }}</ref>

'''David Gustav Epstein''' is the George E. Allen Professor of Law at [[University of Richmond School of Law]] and an expert on [[bankruptcy]].<ref>{{citation|title=Bankruptcy expert appointed Allen Chair|journal=For the Record|publisher=Richmond University School of Law Alumni|date=Summer 2010|url=http://lawmagazine.richmond.edu/Summer_10/for-the-record/for-the-record.php}}.</ref>
Epstein was raised in Texas by a Jewish family.<ref>John Woods, [http://www.chron.com/entertainment/music/article/The-Kinkster-comes-to-class-in-surprise-visit-2093801.php 'The Kinkster' comes to class in surprise visit], New York Law Journal (via Houston Chronicle), October 15, 2002</ref> Epstein received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] from the [[University of Texas]] in 1964, a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from the [[University of Texas School of Law]] in 1966, and an [[LL.M.]] from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1969.<ref name="SMU">[http://www.law.smu.edu/Faculty/Epstein Southern Methodist University biography of David Epstein]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927175842/http://www.law.smu.edu/Faculty/Epstein |date=September 27, 2009 }}</ref> While a student at UT, he became a member of the [[Alpha Epsilon Pi]] Fraternity.<ref name=TexasYB>{{cite book|title=The Cactus|year=1964|publisher=University of Texas|location=Austin, TX|pages=272–273}}</ref> He was also a clerk for the [[Texas Supreme Court]].<ref>[http://tarlton.law.utexas.edu/ttt/participants.html Participant list], Teaching the Teachers Conference, Univ. of Texas, 2007. Retrieved 2009-07-11.</ref>
For twenty-five years, Epstein has been the primary [[BarBri]] lecturer on the topic of [[contract]]s,<ref name="SMU"/> and his lectures have thus been viewed by upwards of a million students. He has coauthored textbooks on bankruptcy, commercial law, contracts, and corporations.<ref name="Haynes">[http://www.worldservicesgroup.com/releases.asp?action=press&pressid=991 SMU Bankruptcy Law Professor David Epstein Joins Haynes and Boone, LLP] (December 2006).</ref> In 2004, the Commercial Law League of America honored him with their Lawrence P. King Award for Excellence in the Field of Bankruptcy.<ref name="clla">{{citation|title=Sua Sponte|journal=Bankruptcy Section Newsletter|publisher=CLLA|url=http://www.cllabankruptcy.org/bankruptcy/september2004.cfm|date=September 2004|first=Alan I.|last=Nahmias}}.</ref>
Epstein has taught at numerous schools and has been the [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of two of them, the [[University of Arkansas School of Law]] and the [[Emory University School of Law]].<ref name="SMU"/><ref>{{citation|title=Emory Law Dean Resigns After Faculty Disputes|journal=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|date=September 28, 1988}}.</ref> He has been a [[tenure]]d law professor at [[Southern Methodist University]], the [[University of North Carolina Law School]], and the [[University of Texas Law School]], the Charles E. Tweedy, Jr. Professor at the [[University of Alabama Law School]],<ref name="clla"/> and a [[visiting professor]] at Harvard, as well as [[Georgetown University Law Center]],<ref>[http://www.law.georgetown.edu/faculty/facinfo/tab_faculty.cfm?Status=Faculty&ID=1778 Faculty profile as an adjunct professor at Georgetown]. Retrieved 2009-07-11.</ref> the [[University of Michigan Law School]], the [[New York University Law School]] and the [[University of Chicago Law School]].<ref name="SMU"/>
In 2006, he became Of Counsel to the [[law firm]] of Haynes and Boone, working out of their office in [[Dallas, Texas]], one day a week.<ref name="Haynes"/>

'''Diamond school''', diamond model, diamond shape and diamond structure are similar terms that apply to a type of [[independent school]] in the UK that combines both single-sex and [[coeducational]] teaching in the same organisation. Typically, the establishment will be [[all-through school|all-through]], often with a nursery setting, and boys and girls are taught together until the age of 11, separately from 11-16, before coming back together again in a joint [[sixth form]].
Diamond schools are often the product of the merger of a boys' and a girls' school, thus it is possible that at [[Key Stage 3|KS3]] and [[Key Stage 4|KS4]] girls and boys can be taught separately on different sites. It is a common feature that boys and girls combine outside the classroom in activities for academic trips and visits and in some co-curricular activities, such as choirs, orchestras and the [[Duke of Edinburgh Award]] scheme. Other coeducational schools adopt a "partial" diamond model in which certain subjects (e.g. [[Science,_technology,_engineering,_and_mathematics|STEM]] are taught to gender segregated sets or classes, typically drawn from Key Stages 3 and 4 (Years 7 to 11).
The degree of gender separation has recently been brought into focus by the [[Al-Hijrah School|Al Hijrah]] judicial decision that total gender segregation in coeducational schools is illegal in England and Wales.

{{about|Australian feminist anthropologist, author and activist}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Anthropology of kinship}} '''Diane Robin (Di) Bell''' (born 11 June 1943) is an [[Australian]] [[feminist]] [[anthropologist]], author and [[activist]]. She has a particular focus on the Aboriginal people of Australia, Indigenous land rights, human rights, Indigenous religions, violence against women, and on environmental issues. She is Professor Emerita of [[Anthropology]] at the [[George Washington University]] in Washington, D.C., and Writer and Editor in Residence at [[Flinders University]], [[South Australia]]. Bell was born in and grew up in Melbourne. In 2005, after 17 years in the United States, she returned to Australia and worked on a number of projects in South Australia. Bell lives and writes in Canberra.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diane Bell- The Conversation|url=https://theconversation.com/profiles/diane-bell-1642|website=The Conversation|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
Her books include ''Daughters of the Dreaming'' (1983/93); ''Generations: Grandmothers, mothers, and daughters'' (1987); ''Law: The old and the new'' (1980); ''Religion in Aboriginal Australia'' (co-edited 1984); and ''Radically Speaking: Feminism reclaimed'' (co-edited 1996). ''Ngarrindjeri Wurruwarrin: A world that is, was, and will be'' (1998) won a NSW Premier's Literary Award and was shortlisted for the Age Book of the Year Award, the Queensland Premier's History Award and the Australian Literary Society Gold Medallion. ''Evil: A novel'' (2005) was made into a play and performed in DC and Adelaide. She also wrote ''Kungun Ngarrindjeri Miminar Yunnan: Listen to Ngarrindjeri Women Speaking'' (2008).<ref>{{cite web|title=The Conversation: Diane Bell|url=https://theconversation.com/profiles/diane-bell-1642|website=The Conversation|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
== Work life as a teacher, researcher, consultant, writer and editor == Bell trained as a primary teacher in the 1960s in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia. She returned to study in the 1970s but first had to complete high school which she did by attending night school at [[Box Hill High School]], Victoria.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Diane|first1=Bell|title=The Songlines Conversations with Gregg Borschmann|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/bigideas/the-songlines-conversations-diane-bell/3321258#transcript|website=www.abc.net.au|publisher=ABC Radio National|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref> Bell continued onto university and received her BA (Hons) in Anthropology at [[Monash University]] in 1975, and a Ph.D. from [[Australian National University]] (ANU) in 1981 which was based on field work with Aboriginal women in central Australia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Diane|first1=Bell|title=The Encyclopedia of Women & Leadership in Twentieth-Century Australia|url=http://www.womenaustralia.info/leaders/biogs/WLE0596b.htm|website=www.womenaustralia.info|publisher=Australian Women's Archives Project 2014|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref>
During the 1980s, Bell held a range of positions in Australia. She worked for the [[Northern Territory]] Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority in the early 1980s, before establishing her own anthropological consultancy in Canberra. She consulted for the [[Central Land Council]], the [[Northern Land Council]], Aboriginal Legal Aid Services, the [[Australian Law Reform Commission]], and the Aboriginal Land Commissioner. She subsequently held academic posts, first as a Research Fellow at the ANU, and then as the Chair of Australian Studies at [[Deakin University]] in Geelong where she was the first female professor on staff.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article118126360 |title=Professorial post. |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=20 June 1986 |accessdate=1 January 2015 |page=9 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In 1989, Bell moved to the United States to take up the Chair of Religion, Economic Development and Social Justice endowed by the [[Henry Luce|Henry R. Luce Foundation]], at the [[College of the Holy Cross]] in Worcester, Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kuzniewsk|first1=Anthony|title=Thy Honored Name: A History of the College of the Holy Cross, 1843-1994|date=1999|publisher=The Catholic University of America Press|location=USA|pages=453, 465}}</ref> In 1999 she moved to Washington, D.C. where she was Director of Women's Studies and Professor of Anthropology at the George Washington University (GWU). As the recipient of a fellowship in 2003-4, awarded by the peak educational body, the American Council on Education (ACE), Bell also worked closely with the senior administration of [[Virginia Tech]] as they revised their curriculum.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Clara B.|title=Virginia Tech Hosts One Of Nation's 37 ACE Fellows|url=https://vtechworks.lib.vt.edu/bitstream/handle/10919/20596/2003-285.html?sequence=1|website=vetchworks.lib.vt.edu|publisher=Virginia Tech University|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref> Bell served on the Board of Trustees for [[Hampshire College]] for eight years.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Diane|first1=Bell|title=Trustee Emeriti|url=https://www.hampshire.edu/offices/trustees-emeriti|website=Hampshire College|publisher=Hampshire College|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref> On her retirement from GWU in 2005 she was awarded the title "Professor Emerita of Anthropology" by The George Washington University. On her return to Australia she was appointed Writer and Editor in Residence at Flinders University (South Australia) and Visiting Professor, School of Social Sciences at the University of Adelaide (South Australia).
Bell is the author/editor of 10 books, including several significant monographs on Australian Aboriginal culture and numerous articles and book chapters dealing with religion, land rights, law reform, art, history and social change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asap.unimelb.edu.au/bsparcs/biogs/P004459b.htm|title=Bell, Diane - Biographical entry - Encyclopedia of Australian Science|first=The University of Melbourne eScholarship Research|last=Centre|website=www.asap.unimelb.edu.au}}</ref> She has served on the editorial boards of several journals (''Aboriginal History'' 1979–1988; ''[[Women's Studies International Forum]]'' 1990-) and was a contributing member of the Editorial Board for the ''Longmans Encyclopedia'' (1989) Macmillan, ''Encyclopedia of World Religions'' (2005) and the ''Encyclopedia of Religion in Australia'' (2009).
Bell was a contributing consultant to ''National Geographic'' on their ''Taboo'' TV series (2002-4).
==Anthropological work== {{More citations needed|date=March 2018}} Bell's first full-length anthropological monograph was ''Daughters of the Dreaming'', which focused on the religious, spiritual and ceremonial lives of Aboriginal women in central Australia.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bowdler|first1=Sarah|title=Review of Daughters of the Dreaming by D. Bell.|journal=Australian Archaeology|date=1984|issue=19|pages=116–117|url=https://www.library.uq.edu.au/ojs/index.php/aa/article/view/1755/1737 |accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref> The book has been in continuous print since its first publication in 1983 and subsequent editions in 1993 and 2002 engage with the debates the work stimulated. It is now well-established practice to have women's councils as part of the decision-making and consultative structures in Aboriginal affairs. Through her research and in giving expert evidence, Bell has been able to demonstrate that Aboriginal women are owners and managers of land in their own right. Bell worked on some 10 land claims for the Central Land Council, the Northern Land Council and the then Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey.
In 1986, Melbourne publishers McPhee Gribble, with Bell as author, won the competitive tender from the Australian Bicentennial Authority (ABA) to write a book about women in Australia for the 1988 Bicentenary. The book, ''Generations: Grandmothers, Mothers and Daughters'' (with photos by Ponch Hawkes) explored generations of Australian women and "the way the significant objects in their lives have been passed from hand to hand, generation to generation".<ref>from the back page blurb of the Penguin edition of ''Generations''</ref> It focused on ordinary people through the stories they had been told by and were passing onto their female kin.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article101972973 |title=Bicentenary books enshrine Australian women's arts. |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=30 January 1988 |accessdate=1 January 2015 |page=13 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Bell used an ethnographic approach to explore the commonalities of Australian women's cultures across age, time, race and region. Shortly after it was published, the book reached number one on the ''Age'' best seller list for works of non-fiction.
Throughout the latter part of the 1970s, and through most of the 1980s, Bell was involved in issues about Aboriginal land rights and law reform. With lawyer, Pam Ditton, she authored ''Law: the old and the new. Aboriginal Women in Central Australia Speak Out'' (Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service, 1980) which addressed issues of law reform in Central Australia, in the wake of the passage of the Northern Territory Land Rights Act (1976). Bell worked on a number of land claim cases in the Northern Territory, particularly in central Australia, but also in and around the [[Top End]].
In the late 1990s, Bell became a key player in the [[Hindmarsh Island bridge controversy]]. In 1994 a group of [[Ngarrindjeri]] women, traditional owners of the Lower River Murray, Lakes Alexandrina and Albert and the Coorong (South Australia) had objected that a proposal to build a bridge from Goolwa to Kumarangk (Hindmarsh Island) near the Murray Mouth would desecrate sites sacred to them as women. The gender restricted knowledge that underwrote their claim became known as 'secret women's business' and was contested in the media, courts and academy. In 1996 a South Australian Royal Commission found that the women had deliberately fabricated their beliefs to thwart the development. However, the women who claimed knowledge of the sacred tradition did not give evidence at the Royal Commission because they considered it to be a violation of their religious freedoms. Five years later these women and those experts who had testified on their behalf were vindicated. In 2001, federal court judge, Mr John von Doussa, heard from all parties to the dispute and found the women had not lied. Nonetheless the notion that the women lied persists in some quarters and 'secret women's business' is used as a term of derision and disrespect. Bell became involved in this matter of gender-restricted knowledge after the Royal Commission. On the basis of her research in the SA archives and fieldwork with the women in 1996-8, Bell was convinced there was sufficient evidence to support the women's claims that there was gender-restricted knowledge in Ngarrindjeri society and that the women had told the truth.
Bell's subsequent monograph, ''Ngarrindjeri Wurruwarrin'' (1998), won the [[New South Wales Premier's Literary Awards#Gleebooks Prize for Critical Writing|NSW Premier's Gleebook Award]] for cultural and literary criticism in 1999. The judges wrote: "An erudite capacious book on the politically contentious and culturally sensitive subject of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge affair, in which the author allows diverse voices to be heard and refuses to simplify an inherently complicated and pressing set of issues. This is an outstanding book of cultural criticism, which brings together feminist anthropology, oral and archival history, political and legal narrative." The book was also short listed for The Age Book of the Year and the Queensland Premier's History Award in 1999 and the Gold Medal of the Australian Literary Society in 2000. ''Ngarrindjeri Wurruwarrin'' is often cited as an important example of alternate ethnographic prose. Bell's most recent writing with Ngarrindjeri women, ''Kungun Ngarrindjeri Miminar Yunnan'' (2008) is a further contribution to collaborative research and writing and documents the impact of the contesting of cultural knowledge on the Ngarrindjeri. Bell continued to work with the Ngarrindjeri and from 2005–2012 lives on their traditional lands as she researched and wrote the Connection Report for their Native Title Claim.
== Creative writing == {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2015}} Bell has also delved into the writing of fiction and plays. Her first book, titled ''Evil'', addresses secrets within the churches and is set on the campus of an American college. Performed as a play adapted by Leslie Jacobson for the "From Page to Stage" season on new plays at the Kennedy Center, Washington, D.C., USA, 3 September 2006 and presented as a staged reading in Adelaide, 16 May 2008. Her play "Weaving and Whispers" was performed at the TarraWarra Museum of Arts Biennial in 2014. Her short story "Blenders" appeared in ''Island'' magazine 2010.
== Politics == Bell ran as an [[independent (politics)|independent]] candidate in the [[Mayo by-election, 2008|2008 Mayo by-election]], caused by the resignation of former foreign minister and [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] leader [[Alexander Downer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24165734-5013871,00.html|title=Anthropologist and author Diane Bell throws hat into Mayo ring: The Australian 12/8/2008|website=news.com.au}}</ref> Her campaign was called Vote4Di and was supported by a campaign website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vote4di.com/index.html|archive-url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/88408/20080904-1524/vote4di.com/index.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=4 September 2008|title=G'day, Di here|author=Di Bell|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> South Australian independent Senator [[Nick Xenophon]] gave support to Bell's campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24215631-5006787,00.html|title=Xenophon backs Bell for Mayo by-election: The Australian 21/8/2008|website=news.com.au}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24235117-5013871,00.html|title=Mayo candidates jockey for votes as saviours of the Murray: The Australian 25/8/2008|website=news.com.au}}</ref> In a field of eleven candidates and the absence of a [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] candidate, Bell finished third on a 16.3 percent primary vote, behind the [[Australian Greens|Greens]] on 21.4 (+10.4) percent and the Liberals on 41.3 (–9.8) percent. The seat became marginal for the Liberals on a 53.0 (–4.0) [[Two-party-preferred vote|two-candidate vote]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vtr.aec.gov.au/HouseDivisionFirstPrefs-13826-188.htm|title=AEC results: Mayo by-election 2008|website=aec.gov.au}}</ref>
== River advocate == {{BLP sources section|date=April 2015}} Bell campaigned for fresh water flows for the River Murray, Lakes Alexandrina and Albert and the Coorong. In 2007, she was a co-founder of the 'StoptheWeir' website and worked with the River, Lakes and Coorong Action Group Inc to stop the construction of a weir across the River Murray at Pomanda Island (at the point where the river enters Lake Alexandrina). She administered the "Hurry Save The Murray" website <ref>{{cite web|url=http://hurrysavethemurray.com/index.html|archive-url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/104642/20120904-0114/hurrysavethemurray.com/index.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=4 September 2012|title=Hurry Save The Murray|accessdate=2 April 2015}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=April 2015|reason=Cited source makes no mention of Bell having administered website. Just says she began project to document changing conditions.}} and has been a frequent speaker and commentator on environmental matters on line, in the media and in preparing submissions and giving evidence to various environmental inquiries.
==Works==

Melbourne, McPheeGribble/Sydney, Allen and Unwin, 1983 (Second ed. Minneapolis, University of Minnesota Press 1993; Third ed. Melbourne, Spinifex Press 2002) *''Law: The Old and the New'' (with Pam Ditton) Aboriginal History, Canberra, 1980

{{Infobox school | name = Distance Education Centre Victoria (DECV) | logo =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:DECv.jpg]] --> | type = [[Public school (government funded)|Public]] ([[Distance Education]]) | founded = 1909 | location = 315 Clarendon Street | city = [[Thornbury, Victoria|Thornbury]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|45|42|S|145|1|34|E|region:AU-VIC_type:edu|display=inline,title}} | principal = Bretton New | free_label = Focus | free_text = All, No particular | enrolment = approx 3,000 <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.distance.vic.edu.au/about/abtover.htm | title = About DECV - an Overview | accessdate = 2006-08-07 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060819195210/http://www.distance.vic.edu.au/about/abtover.htm | archivedate = 2006-08-19 | df = }}</ref> | staff = 160 | mascot = | homepage = [http://www.distance.vic.edu.au/ www.distance.vic.edu.au] }}
'''Distance Education Centre Victoria''' ('''DECV''') is a school located in [[Thornbury, Victoria|Thornbury]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], in [[Melbourne]]'s north. It aims to provide flexible learning opportunities to Victorian F-12 students who are unable to attend mainstream schooling.
==Students== The DECV exists to meet the educational needs of Victorian students whose circumstances prevent them from accessing mainstream schooling. In order to directly enrol with the DECV students must fall under one of five enrolment categories and provide certain pieces of documented evidence alongside their application.<ref>{{cite web|title=DECV Eligibility Criteria|url=http://www.distance.vic.edu.au/eligibility-criteria/|accessdate=9 February 2016}}</ref>
''Category 1 – medical:'' students enrolling in this category must have a specialist diagnosis of a chronic medical condition or treatment for a condition which means they are not physically able to attend a mainstream school for an extended period of time.
''Category 2 – travel:'' students enrolling in this category must be Victorian residents who are unable to attend a mainstream school because they are travelling within Victoria, Australia or overseas. Travel may be required due to a parent’s work commitments or an extended family holiday.
''Category 3 – sports and performance:'' students enrolling in this category must have elite sporting or performing arts commitments which prevent them from being able to attend mainstream school. These commitments may include performance or training commitments during regular school times, or extended interstate or international travel for training or competition. Many children wanting to ‘dance’ like become a ballerina or ballet dancer use this program so they can do half time or full day at their dance school.
''Category 4 – distance:'' students enrolling in this category must be Victorian residents who live in a remote area where it is not feasible to travel to a local mainstream government school. The requirements for enrolment in this category vary depending on the Year Level and age of the student.
''Category 5 – young adults:'' students aged at least 17 years of age at the beginning of the semester they wish to commence in, and less than 21 years on 1 January that year, may enrol to study a VCE or VCAL course of study with the DECV.
==The school== The school is based in Thornbury, Victoria. It shares a building with the ''Victorian School of Languages''.
The school is split into two sub-schools: *''F-10 sub-school'', which handles students from Foundation to Year 10; *''Year 11/12 sub-school'', which handles students from Years 11 and 12 (including VCE and VCAL).
==Work== A [[blended learning]] model is employed by the school in the vast majority of subjects, with work completed in online classroom spaces, both synchronous and asynchronous, and physical unit guides. Students are also able to visit the school during normal school hours to meet with teachers, attend seminars and study in the library or purpose built study areas.

[[File:Edmond Duvernoy 1900.jpg|thumb|Edmond Duvernoy]] '''Charles-Henri Edmond Duvernoy''' (16 June 1844{{spaced ndash}}12 January 1927) was a French pianist, [[baritone]] and vocal teacher, from a family of musicians.<ref name="Fetis">Fétis F-J. ''Biographie universelle des musiciens.'' Paris, 1878.</ref>
== Life and career == Edmond Duvernoy was born in [[Paris]]. He was taught initially by his father, Charles-François Duvernoy, then studied at the [[Paris Conservatoire]]. A fine pianist, he began to teach, then studied singing, joining the [[Opéra-Comique]] company.<ref name="Fetis"/> He made his stage debut as Mercutio in the first performance at the Opéra-Comique of [[Charles Gounod|Gounod]]'s ''[[Roméo et Juliette]]'' on 20 January 1873. He also sang Moralès in the premiere of [[Georges Bizet|Bizet]]'s ''[[Carmen]]'' in 1875; Bizet composed three versions of the ''mélodrame'' in Act 1 for Duvernoy.
According to Malherbe, he had a relatively soft voice, but he used it with good taste, and with sufficient talent to enable him to become later one of the most esteemed vocal teachers.<ref name="Soubies">Soubies A, Malherbe C. ''Histoire de l'opéra comique — La seconde salle Favart 1840–1887.'' Flammarion, Paris, 1893.</ref>
He sang Ganymède in ''Galathée'' in 1873, alongside his future wife, Mlle Franck, a soprano of the Opéra-Comique.<ref name="Soubies"/> Duvernoy and his wife moved to the Théâtre-Lyrique in 1877. Both of them participated in the private 'premiere' of Offenbach’s ''[[The Tales of Hoffmann|Les contes d'Hoffmann]]'' on 18 May 1879, Duvernoy playing the piano.<ref>Wolff, Stéphane. ''Un demi-siècle d'Opéra-Comique 1900–1950.'' André Bonne, Paris, 1953.</ref>
From October 1887 to 1910 Duvernoy was a singing professor at the [[Conservatoire de Paris]], with many important artists among his pupils including [[Aino Ackté]]. He also composed some songs.
He died in Paris in 1927, aged 82. His brother was [[Alphonse Duvernoy]], pianist and composer.

[[File:Flogstaskriket.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|View of Sernanders väg in [[Flogsta]], [[Uppsala]]]] '''Elvavrålet''' (Swedish: the eleven roar) is a [[student]] [[tradition]] where students at universities and colleges at a certain time every evening/night in student residential areas (22:00 or 23:00, on Lappkärrsberget only Tuesdays) open their windows, go out onto balconies or up to the rooftops and scream out their [[anxiety]] due to exams and [[stress (psychological)|stress]].
The roar is also called ''the Delphi roar'' (after the student residential area Delphi in [[Lund]]), ''the Flogsta roar''<ref>[http://www.sfi.se/sv/svensk-filmdatabas/Item/?type=MOVIE&itemid=73915 ''Flogstavrålet''] (2013) på [[Svensk Filmdatabas]]</ref><ref>[http://www.unt.se/student/flogstavralet-aterupptackt-tradition-360307.aspx ''Flogstavrålet återupptäckt tradition''], [[Upsala Nya Tidning]], 2 mars 2006</ref> (after the neighborhood [[Flogsta]] in [[Uppsala]]), ''the Lappkärr cry'' (after the neighborhood Lappkärrsberget in [[Stockholm]]), ''the Ten cry'', ''the Tuesday scream'' or ''Anxiety scream''. On some days there are more roars than others, and sometimes even [[vuvuzela]]s are used. The phenomenon has been known since the 1970s, and has also been the subject of academic papers and discussions on the radio.
==References== <references />
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091027152618/http://geocities.com/korridoren_flogsta/flogstaskriket.html Flogstavrålet som mp3-fil] (arkiverad från [https://web.archive.org/web/20091027152618/http://www.geocities.com/korridoren_flogsta/flogstaskriket.html Original]) * [http://blogg.aftonbladet.se/21512/perma/742843/ blog description (se)] * [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/12/flogsta-scream-sweden_n_2462868.html ''Flogsta scream tradition would annoy our neighbors for sure (VIDEO)''] [[Huffington Post]], 2013-01-13 * [http://www.unt.se/inc/print/livet-i-korridoren-1435912-default.aspx ''Livet i korridoren''], [[Upsala Nya Tidning]], 2011-08-25 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dJamX-x6wWc ''Flogsta scream'', June 7 2007 (video)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3lgQ9u5B9nA ''Last flogsta scream'', June 2007 (video)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2SOm72WHj1E ''Delphivrålet'', March 2010 (video)]

{{Infobox person | name = Freda Betti | image = | caption = Portrait of Freda Betti. | birth_name = Frédérique Thérèse Augusta Betti | birth_date = {{birth date|1924|02|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Nice]], [[France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1979|11|13|1924|02|26|df=y}} | death_place = [[Nice]], [[France]] | death_cause = [[Suicide]] | burial_place = [[Cimetière du Château]] | residence = [[Levallois-Perret]] | nationality = [[French nationality law|French]] | education = [[Conservatory of Nice]] | occupation = [[Opera singer]]
[[Singing teacher]] | years active = 1947–1979 | spouse = {{marriage|René Clermont|1949|1976|reason=his death}} | children = 2 | notable_works = ''[[Carmen]]'' }} '''Freda Betti''' (26 February 1924 – 13 November 1979), whose birth name was '''Frédérique Thérèse Augusta Betti''', was a French [[mezzo-soprano]] singer whose career was mainly confined to France.[http://www.cpanda.org/pdfs/csob/2301.pdf ''Central Opera Service bulletin'', Volume 23, No. 1]. (1981). Obituary: Freda Betti. p. 39 She left a range of recordings representative of her repertoire. == Biography == Freda Betti was born at 52 rue des Ponchettes in the district of ''Vieux-Nice'' in a modest family : her father was a house painter and her mother a fishmonger. His paternal family originates from the region of [[Emilia-Romagna]] in [[Italy]] : his grandfather was born in [[Parma]] and he immigrated to [[Nice]] with his wife and children in 1893.[http://viaf.org/processed/DNB%7C129638838 Years of birth and death in the German National Library] accessed 27 December 2014. She studied music and especially singing at the [[Conservatory of Nice]] with Édouard Rouard,[https://books.google.com/books?ei=2NfQUKauFYaGhQef84CgBQ&hl=en&id=5y4KAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22freda+betti%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22freda+betti%22 Obituary for Freda Betti in ''[[Opera (magazine)|Opera]]'', Vol 31, p299, 1980.] accessed 27 December 2014. where she obtained a ''Premier Prix de Chant'' in 1943. She made her debut at the [[Opéra de Monte-Carlo]] in 1947 as Siébel in ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]'' by [[Charles Gounod]]. She appeared frequently with the [[Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France]] of the [[Radiodiffusion-Télévision Française|RTF]] in the early 1950s, before entering the troupe of the [[Opéra-Comique]] in the 1960s. She sang the title role in particular of ''[[Carmen]]'' by [[Georges Bizet]] which she sang more than 150 times, and her repertoire also included Fricka, Brangaene, Dulcinée in ''[[Don Quichotte]]'' and Suzuki. Betti sang on major national stages ([[Théâtre Graslin|Nantes]], [[Opéra de Nice|Nice]], [[Strasbourg Music Festival|Strasbourg]], [[Théâtre du Capitole|Toulouse]]) and European ([[Opéra de Monte-Carlo|Monte-Carlo]], [[La Scala]]), as well as in numerous opera festivals, including [[Aix-en-Provence Festival|Aix-en-Provence]], [[Festival d'Avignon|Avignon]], [[Bayreuth Festival|Bayreuth]]. Betti recorded for [[Philips Records|Philips]] and [[EMI Records|EMI]]. Among published recordings she took part in were ''[[Snegurochka (opera)|The Snow Maiden]]'' (Bobilicka),[http://www.operadis-opera-discography.org.uk/CLRISNOW.HTM Listing of 1955 radio recording of ''The Snow Maiden'' conducted by [[Charles Bruck]] at the Operadiscography site] accessed 27 December 2014.
